page.title: 06Local History - Name Origin
page.content: The Isle of May has been a place of note for over a thousand years. the name of May or Maia seems to have some affinity with the Maeote, the name of a tribe of Picts. It is probable that a colony of these people first took possession of the island and gave it the name Maia. The Maeote were people who dwelt between the walls of Hadrian and Antonine. Another possible derivation of the name is Scandinavian, as it also occurs in Caithness, where most of the place names are derived from that language. The Scandinavian meaning refers to the luxuriant plant life of the place.
